Title.En: Intercomprehension and Intercultural Skills in Romance and Germanic Languages

Description.En:
Are you eager to navigate the rich tapestry of European languages and cultures, enhancing your communication skills and intercultural competence? If so, this micro-module is designed for you!

In this engaging and dynamic course, you will explore the fascinating concept of intercomprehension – the ability to understand a language without having studied it formally. This skill is invaluable in our interconnected world, where grasping multiple languages opens doors to diverse opportunities. You’ll delve into 12 languages, including French, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, Catalan, Romanian, English, German, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian, and Danish, tailoring your learning to match your linguistic background.

But it’s not just about languages. This module immerses you in the cultural nuances that shape communication and worldviews. Working in multilingual and multicultural teams, you will gain hands-on experience in collaborative projects, enhancing your intercultural awareness. You’ll also get the chance to participate in a unique escape game that will challenge you to apply everything you've learned in a fun, interactive setting.

Throughout the course, you’ll maintain a reflective journal to track your progress and insights, enhancing your self-reflection skills. This practice will help you critically evaluate your learning process and adapt your strategies for better outcomes.

By the end of this module, you will have strengthened your linguistic abilities and your capacity to work effectively in diverse teams, a skill highly valued in today’s globalised job market. Join us and embark on a journey that will expand your horizons, deepen your cultural understanding, and equip you with practical skills for the future.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**Teaching Format**

This training module is based on participatory workshops and autonomous student work. It comprises 7 workshops with some autonomous work and 1 evaluation session. Outside class time, online activities will favour intercultural interactions between the students. The sessions will be held in hybrid mode: on-site at INSA Toulouse on Mondays from 2pm to 5pm (CET) and online for remote students. The sessions should preferably be followed synchronously on Mondays from 2pm to 5pm (CET), but can be followed online asynchronously during the same week, except for the last two sessions, which need to take place synchronously due to group work. However, for these last two sessions, the schedule can be arranged between the students in the same team and the teacher

**Detailed programme**

The content will be delivered iteratively, meaning that students will revisit and reinforce previously learned techniques while integrating new ones, thus allowing for continuous improvement and deeper understanding. Most of the activities will be based on group work on different types of written documents, and will also include some oral communication activities in the different languages. Outside class time, online activities will be planned to favour intercultural interactions between the students.

- **October 07 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:**Introductory session: Presentation of the micromodule, introduction to the principles of intercomprehension and first practice exercises in groups
- **October 14 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:** Workshop 1 (possibly asynchronous): Introduction to the “Seven Sieves” (Klein, H. G. *The Seven Sieves: How to Read All the Romance Languages Right Away*. Shaker Verlag, Aachen 2003); Focus on international and pan-Romance/pan-Germanic vocabulary
- **October 21 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:**Workshop 2 (possibly asynchronous): Focus on sound correspondences
- **November 4 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:**Workshop 3 (possibly asynchronous): Focus on spelling and pronunciation
- **November 18 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:** Workshop 4 (possibly asynchronous): Focus on sentence structure (syntax)
- **November 25 (2-5pm) / possibly asynchronous:** Workshop 5 (possibly asynchronous): Focus on prefixes and suffixes and morphosyntax
- **December 02 (2-5pm) MUST be synchronous / if needed timing can be re-arranged with teacher & fellow students in the same team:** Linguistic escape game in teams, which will serve as a basis for the Final Group Debrief on Dec 9
- **December 09 (2-5pm) MUST be synchronous / if needed timing can be re-arranged with teacher & fellow students in the same team:**Final Group Oral Debrief (10 min per group + Q&A)

Please note that this schedule is subject to change as adjustments may be made based on the pace of the course and students’ needs.

**Evaluation**

You will be evaluated using the followinng activites. Please note that you will either pass or fail the micromodule.

- Individual Learning Journal: Weekly entries with a final reflection on the skills acquired, progress made and strategies employed.
- Group Oral Debrief (10 min per group + Q&A): Following a collaborative project (e.g. escape game) in multilingual and intercultural teams, analyse the linguistic strategies used and the intercultural situations encountered.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral: Understand Languages You Have Never Learnt in an Intercultural Context

Discover the fascinating world of intercomprehension! This micromodule introduces you to strategies for understanding and communicating across twelve Romance and Germanic languages (French, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, Catalan, Romanian, English, German, Dutch, Swedish, Norwegian and Danish). Tailored to fit each student's linguistic background, this course emphasizes playful and interactive learning to help your broaden your linguistic horizons.

**To apply for this micromodule you should:**

- have a B2 level of English language proficiency
- have some basic knowledge of at least one Romance language (French, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, Romanian, etc.) OR one Germanic language (German, Dutch, Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, Icelandic).

**There are no explicit domaine prerequisites**, but an open attitude towards foreign languages, interdisciplinary team work and international competences are required

**Documents to be submitted by 20/09/2024:**

- Short motivation letter (max. 250 words) - personal motivation to join the micromodule, interest in foreign languages, experience with other foreign languages, etc.
- Transcript of records - enrolment in a Bachelor's or Master’s degree programme and completed ECTS.

- One-Page Curriculum Vitae (CV) including:
    - Name
    - Last Name
    - Nationality
    - Date of birth
    - City of birth
    - Current address
    - Email
    - Telephone
    - Languages and corresponding CEFR levels (between A1 and C2)
